data.title: British Keyboard Layout: System keymaps overridden
data.body:
The system keymaps appear to have been overridden in the latest release. In all other applications using cmd + ` scrolls through all the open windows in that application. In the latest version it splits the editor window.

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Open another VSCode window
3. Attempt to scroll through the VSCode windows using cmd + ` 
4. It splits the current editor and doesn't scroll though open VSCode windows

data.title: Neo keyboard layout: Some Keys stopped working

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T21:13:24.700Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-72-generic

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install and activate [Neo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyboard_layout#Neo) keyboard layout
2. Open any source file in VS code
3. Put cursor somewhere in the file
4. Press `M4` key and hold. Press `s` key (see image)
5. Instead of the cursor moving left, nothing happens

In the previous version of VSCode (1.10.2 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331) this worked just fine .

![tastatur_e4b png](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378106/24753062/df9a58fe-1ad0-11e7-9713-af281be3b7af.png)

data.title: Prevent adding a new source in sources.list.d
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 Commit 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331
- OS Version: Linux 4.4.0-66-generic #87~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Fri Mar 3 17:32:36 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VS Code from a local repository mirror
2. VS Code automatically updates `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/vscode.list`
3. My distribution prevents downloads from "foreign" debian repositories for security reasons, and complains about this

It'd be nice if we could somehow avoid adding that repo, in particular as the .deb in this case already comes from that repo.

data.title: Diff/search doesn't work, when a git projects is in an network folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

Diff:
1. open a git project in vscode
2. modify a file, which was already committed
3. go to "source control" -> open changes
4. on the left side, there is only one line and on the right is every thing new

Search:
1. open a git project in vscode
2. enter search value
3. no results

data.title: Renaming a file with just character casing changes and editing it with any editor action like rename symbol, opens a file with the previous name and edits it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:59:05.375Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|rest-client|humao|0.14.0|
|mssql|ms-mssql|0.3.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.2|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.13|
|sort-imports|peterjuras|2.3.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.5.1|;


---

I'm not even sure I have correctly titled this... But for whatever is worth here's the steps...

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file, typescript in my case (reproduced with C# file as well), let's say `test.ts`.
2. Rename it changing just the character case, like `test.ts` -> `Test.ts` (or change casing for all letters, doesn't matter as long as only character casing is changed) using rename from folder view.
3. Rename a symbol using right-click, or just reference a module and import it using `Ctrl + .`, just so the file is edited not manually but by an editor action.
4. The previously named file will open in the editor with the change that was made, so `test.ts` will open and include the change made and `Test.ts` will still show contents without changes.
5. Save the `test.ts` file, close it, now`Test.ts` shows the correct contents.
6. Repeat steps with any change that is done by the editor (like rename symbol) and this goes on indefinitely, a file with the previous name is opened. So a new rename to `TEST.ts` followed by an editor action like rename symbol, will open `Test.ts`.
7. Do any manual change in the file and just save it, the file is saved without opening the file with the previous name and shows correct content as expected.

This happens with git tracked files as well as entirely new files not yet tracked by git. Moreover, it happens with and rename that is only a character case change, doesn't matter how many character casings are done, so `Test`, `TEST` etc. should behave the same.

data.title: Could I change the color of occurrences highlight?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T21:13:24.700Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-46-generic

Actually, My vision is bad. So sometimes I will meet some trouble in Visual studio, Like this:
I selected word by using `Ctrl+D`. And I could not recognize which words were I selected and which words just occurrences highlight.

![2017-04-06 18-26-34](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4303130/24749798/028cf328-1af7-11e7-919a-fb3dd2677c39.png)

Actually, I update my VSCode to latest version. And I found the option `editor.occurrencesHighlight`.But I could not turn off it. Because I should know which words same sometimes.

So could you add an option to setting occurrences highlight color? or other quick way I could change this color by editing some file in VSCode?

Thanks

data.title: Git resources file paths end with `.git`

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Win

JShint extension somehow finds problems in non-existent files, named ``[existent-file].git``. The file, when opened via Problems panel, appears to be readonly and it doesn't correspond to anything in the project folder explorer view.

I would blame JShint and issue a ticket there, but I don't think JShint is the culprit since it shouldn't even be possible for it (or any other extension) to see this data.

In this case I do have ``platform.js`` in my project root
![](https://drive.google.com/uc?id=0B-OJBofmehO3Q3JiVXJKejZrYzA)
![](https://drive.google.com/uc?id=0B-OJBofmehO3dE1ja281cUdMU0U)

data.title: Errors in files of the workspace not counted in the status bar
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: MacOs X 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I open a website folder in VS Code (if I understand well this folder is now the workspace)
2. This folder contains scss files with errors
3. But the status bar shows 0 error and 0 warning
4. I have to open the files with errors to finally have the status bar showing the errors (scss errors)
5. So the problem is that the errors are only reported in the status bar for the open editors and not for the files in the whole workspace.

Thanks in advance to solve this problem.

Kind regards,
Olivier

data.title: Feature request: git checkout command with given branch/ref
data.body:
As proposed [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15525#issuecomment-292114741) I would like to reuse the git commands for my extension. This will result in a lot better user experience since e.g. statusbar updates are instant.

Most valuable would be `git.checkout` with a given branch name or ref.

cc: @joaomoreno

data.title: "search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault" usage unclear
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04

`"search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault": true` not working, I tried everything, restarted VS Code, but issue still same.

I write in `.gitignore`:
```
# Compiled client src
dist
```
And still search is working in that dir, it isn't excluded... Right now working only this option:
```
  // Configure glob patterns for excluding files and folders in searches
  "search.exclude": {
    "**/node_modules": true, // Node modules
    "**/dist": true // Compiled client src
  },
```

`.gitignore` is in the root, here is the project -> https://github.com/svipben/react-boilerplate

data.title: Why intellesense for installed node modules  is not showing until I press Ctrl + space for typescript in vs code version : 1.11.0
data.body:
I upgraded to vs code version 1.11.0 and opened my project. When I try to use import statement in the code, code completion is not working for installed node module name until I press ctr + space. But previously (before upgrade) when I start type the node module name in (import {foo} from 'fo') I see suggestions. for foo file but now (after upgrade) it is not working. 

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. use vs code version 1.11.0
2. install a node module
3. Try to import the node module in a ts file or try to require the node module in js file.
```
import {foo} from 'foo'
```
or
```
let foo = require('foo');
```

data.title: Support relative links to files in output tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T21:13:24.700Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-41-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.11.0|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|final-newline|samverschueren|0.3.2|
|join-lines|wmaurer|0.2.2|
|local-history|xyz|1.1.1|;


---

A typical mocha test output includes relative links to files such as:
```
  1 failing
  1) Test fails:
     AssertionError: expected false to be true
      at Context.<anonymous> (test/test.js:4:5)
```
As the path to the source file is not absolute, it's not turned into a link. It would be very helpful if the output tab could detect this kind of file links as well.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `npm install mocha chai`
2. Create a simple test file and run it with `mocha test/test.js`:
```js
const {expect} = require('chai');
describe('Test', function() {
  it('fails', function() {
    expect(false).to.be.true;
  });
});
```

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:59:05.375Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|nord-visual-studio-code|arcticicestudio|0.1.1|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|javadebugger|donjayamanne|0.0.2|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.0|
|LogFileHighlighter|emilast|1.1.1|
|hopscotch|idleberg|0.1.4|
|tabsanity|jedmao|0.0.9|
|docomment|k--kato|0.0.14|
|vscode-rust|kalitaalexey|0.3.11|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.1|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.12.1|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.10.4|
|java|redhat|0.1.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.5.1|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

I have a large text file of urls (120,108 lines), and when I open it in vscode none of the urls are recognized (no underlined or hover, and I can't ctrl+click to open them). It's not a problem with the urls themselves, because if I paste a small number of them into another text file they highlight just fine.

I'm not sure if it's actually broken or just extremely slow, but I've had this file open for 10+ minutes and still nothing is recognized.

data.title: Git branch creation broken in 1.11
data.body:
Creating a new branch from the "checkout branch" input box no longer exists. See steps to reproduce for details. This feels like a regression in the latest version.

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Click the "master" git branch in the bottom left of the window
2. This opens an input box with a list of git branches
3. In previous versions I could type a new branch name and have VS code create the branch, this now seems to just be a list of existing branches


(I've tried closing and re-opening VS code but that doesn't help)

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Click GIT sync icon after commiting changes.
2. GIT panel icons has timer icon. Panel has progress bar. Sync icon has no animation.

data.title: Immediately submit file search
data.body:
Currently, when highlighting text in the editor, and invoking "Find in Files" (Ctrl/Cmd-Shift-F), the side bar is changed to the Search view, and the search input box is filled in with the selected text, but the search is not actually invoked. This change submits the search immediately after the input is changed.

This could have some sort of preference choice (to auto-search or not), but I think this functionality is actually what's expected.

data.title: Remove old Git world
